witnesses.name: Anthoinette fille Nicolas Petit Jean
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: servant in household of accused's relative

harms_alleged.target: her son aged two and a half

timeline.subject: George Parmentier
timeline.details: Preliminary informations begin; accused by niece Chretienne and Mongeotte femme Nicolas Colombain (imprisoned at Arches)

timeline.subject: Multiple witnesses (3-6)
timeline.details: Testimonies of Roucelot, Jandel, Anthoinette, and Chrestienne

timeline.subject: George Parmentier and Mongeotte
timeline.details: Confrontation with Mongeotte, who maintained accusation of seeing him at sabbat

timeline.subject: Mongeotte Colombain
timeline.details: Mongeotte withdraws accusation, saying she made it out of hatred because George had deposed against her and accused her of killing a cow. Retraction made before torture and again before execution.

timeline.subject: George Parmentier
timeline.details: PG des Vosges suggests he be renvoyé (released)

prior_accusations.context: Accused by his niece Chretienne at sabbat
Accused of seeing him at sabbat; later retracted out of hatred
Called him witch 16 years earlier 'par impulsion des autres garcons' (by impulse of other boys)

notable_quotes.speaker: George Parmentier
notable_quotes.french: mon dieu, je vouldrois bien trouver les moyens de me faire mourir
notable_quotes.english: my God, I would very much like to find the means to make myself die
notable_quotes.context: Overheard groaning while being guarded by Nicolas Thouvenin

notable_quotes.speaker: George Parmentier (to Pierre Roucelot)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il vouldroit que s'en soit ja faict
notable_quotes.english: that he wished it were already done
notable_quotes.context: Speaking of the accusations against him

notable_quotes.speaker: George Parmentier
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne scait ou est noirgotte, scait bien ou est morbieu mais n'y a jamais esté et n'a jamais porté escharpe verte mais bien a porté son espée avec une jartiere qui n'estoit verte
notable_quotes.english: that he does not know where Noirgotte is, knows well where Morbieu is but has never been there and never wore a green scarf but did carry his sword with a garter that was not green
notable_quotes.context: Responding to accusations by Chretienne about sabbat attendance

notable_quotes.speaker: George Parmentier
notable_quotes.french: qu'il luy avoit conseillé de vendre ou engager de son bien pour avoir une piece d'argent affin de s'en servir et qu'il y avoit un grand jubilé a Rome et qu'il y deubt aller
notable_quotes.english: that he had advised him to sell or pledge some of his property to have a piece of silver in order to use it and that there was a great jubilee in Rome and he should go there
notable_quotes.context: Explaining his brother's advice to leave

relationships.evidence_text: his mother Jeannon Garnise was accused 16 years earlier
Accused not only by his niece Chretienne
Asked if brother had not wanted him to leave; house of Jean Parmentier
Mongeotte, femme Nicolas Cosme de l'Estraye
Mongeotte femme Nicolas Colombain, currently imprisoned at Arches
Had been in his service since Christmas

economic_context.details: George's brother advised him to sell or pledge property to get money for pilgrimage to Rome during the jubilee

harms_catalog.victim_name: son of Catherine veuve Delon Vincent
harms_catalog.harm_description: Child aged two and a half died suddenly by 'auge de la fontaine' (water trough) outside house of Jean Parmentier; body was not wet; George found holding him
harms_catalog.method_alleged: drowning (though body not wet - suspicious circumstances)

material_culture.context: George said he carried his sword with a garter
Wore with sword; denied it was green (green apparently significant in accusation)
George denied ever wearing a green scarf (mentioned in Chretienne's accusation)

material_culture.object: auge de la fontaine (water trough at fountain)

prior_legal_disputes.description: George had deposed against Mongeotte Colombain and accused her of killing a cow, which she cited as reason for her false accusation against him
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: This became motive for her retracted witchcraft accusation

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Guarded at Arches; expressed suicidal despair to guard

emotional_state_notes: Groaning and expressing suicidal ideation to guard
Wished the accusations were already done/over with

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: During confrontation, George was able to explain Mongeotte's accusation was false; she later retracted, citing hatred because he had accused her of killing a cow

third_parties.name: Jeannon Garnise
third_parties.context: George's mother who had been accused of witchcraft 16 years earlier; source of his bad reputation

third_parties.name: Chretienne (niece)
third_parties.context: Had accused George at sabbat; not among the formal witnesses but mentioned as accuser

third_parties.name: Mongeotte femme Nicolas Colombain
third_parties.context: Imprisoned at Arches; accused George of being at sabbat, then retracted accusation before torture and execution, citing hatred because he accused her of killing a cow

third_parties.name: Nicolas (son of Mengeotte Colombain)
third_parties.context: Had called George witch 16 years earlier 'by impulse of other boys'

third_parties.name: Jean Parmentier

third_parties.context: Was present when George pulled child from water

third_parties.name: Demenge Collenot (late)
third_parties.context: Father of Chrestienne; deceased at time of trial

third_parties.name: Mathieu Mathieu
third_parties.context: His house was near church tower; George accused of climbing tower against his house

extraction_metadata.notes: Remarkable case of release after key accuser retracted testimony. Mongeotte Colombain withdrew her sabbat accusation twice - before torture and before her own execution - stating it was motivated by hatred because George had previously accused her of killing a cow. The PG des Vosges recommended release. George's reputation stemmed from his mother Jeannon Garnise's accusation 16 years prior. Most witnesses testified to reputation but saw no harm. One witness (Catherine) described suspicious death of her young son found in George's hands near water trough, though body wasn't wet. George showed signs of despair in custody. Accusations involved sabbat attendance at locations Noirgotte and Morbieu, and wearing green clothing/scarf. George denied all, offering natural explanations (helping repair church, pulling drowned child from water). Case demonstrates importance of accuser credibility and retracted testimony in trial outcomes.
